climbs.name: Ulysses' Bivouac
climbs.fa: Woody Stark, Dick Webster, February 1967

content.description:
This route climbs up sandy and gritty cracks and lie-backs up to a traverse into a cave. You can rap from the cave (one old bolt..) or climb easy 5th class to the summit.

The climbing aint' all that good, but the cave is very cool.
content.protection: A few small to medium pieces.
content.location: NW Face of Cyclops in Hidden Valley Campground

climbs.name: Thin Red Line
climbs.fa: (TR) Ron Fawcett  1985, FL: Darrel Hensel

content.description: This is the left bolted route on a large blank face at the base of the Northwest Face of Cyclops next or left to The Eye.  Thin face moves follow a "red line" past a bolt to an incut/mantel that lead to another bolt.  The moves out from this are the crux.    Faces the road.  Continuous and hard.

climbs.name: Telegram for Mongo
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel and Rob Raker, 1982

content.description:
Scramble up and right on easy terrain to a large ledge and set a belay. Climb the smooth, dark brown face passing several scoops and holes in the rock (2 bolts) and then continue up aiming for a horizontal crack that leads back right and onto a ledge.

Decent climbing but the bolts are in need of an upgrade.

climbs.name: Surface Tension
climbs.fa: Charles Cole, George Willig, Randy Vogel, and Steven Anderson, 1984

content.description: A classic steep face climb!  A difficult and scary sequence leads up to the first bolt (don't fall here!).  Sustained, exciting, and somewhat runout climbing goes up from there.
content.protection: 4 bolts (3/8"), gear to 3" for the anchor
content.location: Just left of The Eye on the southwest face.

climbs.name: Spaghetti & Chili
climbs.fa: Frank Avela and Jack Knox, May 1986

content.description:
This route ascends the middle of the SW face of Cyclops Rock -- to the right and around the corner if you're facing the Eye from the road.

Start on a right-facing ramp that is separate from the main face and ascends from the ground -- your belayer can find a nice comfortable seat between the base of the ramp and the main wall (which is extremely undercut at this point).  From the top of the ramp, a few fun moves get you around and over a large rounded flake that opens to the left.  Finally, move slightly to the left and ascend juggy plates to a two-bolt anchor.

Single rope rappel or walk-off to the east.
content.protection: Thin rack to around 2".  Two-bolt anchor; can be backed up with a #2 camalot.

climbs.name: Slim Jim
climbs.fa: Jim Angione, Dave Evans & Todd Gordon, September 1991

content.description:
Slim Jim (aka Nightmare on Angione Street)

is a gritty

, generic friction route for the completionist only. Starting from orange ledges climb up and left via gritty scoops to pass very near the right edge of the

Ulysses' Bivouac

cave and then continue to the sub-summit above.

Down-climb

Business Trip

or continue up the upper portion of

Carolyn's Rump

or

Business Trip

to the top of the rock.

All but the middle bolt is currently missing (April 2021) making this a top-rope problem.
content.protection:
1 bolt, gear to 2.5 inches

Originally 3 bolts, 1 for and gear to 2.5 inches

climbs.name: Stairway to Heaven
climbs.fa: Peter Wautlich and Thomas Kraus, November 1986

content.description: Easy terrain leads up and right onto a ledge and the base of a smooth dark face. Finesse your way up, staying right of some prominent holes in the rock and then trend left of the first bulge and continue above passing several horizontal cracks to the top.
content.location:
The steep dark colored face capped by several bulges left of

Leader's Fright

.

climbs.name: Penelope's Walk
climbs.fa: John Wolfe, Dick Webster & Woody Stark, April 1969

content.description:
Go up a left diagonal crack when that crack dwindles choose the path of least resistance and continue up left until you get to a cave.  Move up at to the left of the cave to where it joins Are We Ourselves.  Pull the final (crux) move to the top.

Watch out for loose rock.  Some of the slab is pretty loose.

Reference: Vogel, Randy. (2006). Rock Climbing Joshua Tree West. Falcon Publishing. A great resource.
content.protection: To 2.5 inches; two bolt anchor/rap on top. I suggest walking off to northeast.
content.location:
About 30 feet right of

Spaghetti & Chili

on the southwest face of Cyclops Rock.

climbs.name: Oversight
climbs.fa: Alan Nelson and Randy Burks, March 1983

content.description: Seldom done but worth the effort is this right slanting flare with twin cracks that steepen near the top before ending on a ledge. Continue up and left and then back right on easy terrain to the summit and descend the backside.
content.location:
Just around and left from

Thin Red Line

in a flared corner.

climbs.name: Overnight Sensation
climbs.fa: John Wolfe & Rob Stahl, 11/70, FFA: (TR) Rick Cashner and Don Reid., 1979, FL: Dave Mayville et al, 8/90

content.description: On the Northeast Face, climb up face and cracks past the left side of a big brown scoop. At the right side of another brown scoop, a crack leans up and right. Follow this past a diagonal slash. Move right past a bolt to another right leaning crack and up.

climbs.name: The Official Route of the 1984 Olympics
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel, Charles Cole and Steve Anderson, 1984

content.description:
Start from the desert floor in a scoop and face climb up past some horizontals (pro) to the first bolt about 40' up. Interesting friction past two more bolts leads up and right to the left margin of a small cave/recess where you will find another bolt. Steep friction moves (crux) lead to the security of a good hold after which the climbing eases and some gear can be placed. One final bolt protects the moves to the top where a bolted anchor will be found. Either rappel off or do the walk-off down the backside which is quick and easy.

Those who like spicy steep friction will enjoy this route out as it offers engaging climbing with a minimal approach. A little sporty but safe, this route is perhaps best done on a cool day or when shady for maximum security.

About the name - the 1984 summer Olympics were held in Los Angeles and at that time everything it seemed was marketed with the Official Olympic tie-in, so it seemed only natural to have an "Official Route".
content.protection: 5 bolts (1/2"), light rack to 2 inches, bolted anchor.
content.location:
Right of

The Eye

(a prominent window above a deep recessed area in the rock) lies a large ledge located about 40' off the ground. The smooth and unbroken face right of the ledge is where you'll find this route.

climbs.name: Odysseus' Shuffle
climbs.fa: Sean Tang, Hannah Ashley, 9/2017

content.description: Start on the far right end of the west face and ascend the most prominent diagonal ramp up and leftward to the anchor bolts atop Spaghetti & Chili. About halfway where this main diagonal starts to dwindle, instead of veering lower toward the "cave" along Penelope's Walk, continue onward across that dwindling diagonal past its narrowest for exposed shuffling excitement, before it broadens again for the last few walking steps to the anchor bolts. Another route called Goldilocks (rated 5.7 in the books) crosses path near midway to go up and over two small roofs onto a lower sloping topout, if one needs an earlier easier bailout exit.
content.protection: Pro to 2.5", bolted anchor hangers without rap rings. Walk off.

climbs.name: New Year's Day
climbs.fa: Bob & Yvonne Gaines

content.description:
This route is located between Are We Ourselves and Grey Cell Green.  Start by climbing 10' or so to a bolt at the bottom of a large scoop, then head straight up over a bulging left-facing flake - small cam behind the flake if you trust it.  After manteling on top of the flake, clip the pin buried in a seam above (easy to miss).  Then diagonal up and right to the anchors atop Grey Cell Green.  Start the second pitch by moving up and left to the first bolt on a vague arete, then follow bolts and pins straight up to the top of the formation.

The last bolt has a bail link on it - don't quit now!  The moves above the bolt are steep, but a few better-than-expected edges will get you to the final short exit crack.

Fun route that will get better as it cleans up.  Two stars out of five.
content.protection: Not quite a sport route - with only one bolt and one pin on the first pitch, some will want a small cam as well.  The second pitch is well protected with pins and bolts, although a hand-sized cam can be used to protect the final short exit crack.

climbs.name: Leader's Fright
climbs.fa: Jim Foote, Woody Stark, Dick Webster 1966

content.description: The route is the obvious crack on the extreme right of the northwest face of Cyclops. Setting protection is a bit problematic, and tis a bit runout in one spot. This route acquired its name due to a leader fall on the FA. FA 1966.

climbs.name: The I
climbs.fa: Todd & Donette Swain 01-2008

content.description: Directly across from Masochism on the Potato Head are two parallel right slanting cracks on the lower north face of the Cyclops. Climb the left crack, finishing with an overhang formed by a boulder (height related  harder if short).

climbs.name: Gray Cell Green
climbs.fa: Don Wilson and Todd Gordon, February 1992

content.description:
Boulder up the start until possible to clip the first bolt then work your way left to clip a second bolt. Good footwork will make the somewhat crimpy moves to the third bolt easier. Climb past a final bolt and finish up with easier moves via a short hand crack onto a ledge with anchors.

A short route that is decent enough worth doing if in the area. Originally there was another fixed pin before the first bolt - it may be possible to get a small (0.5")piece in if necessary. Additionally one can get a 2.5" piece in the crack section at the top if needed.

The hard moves and the bulk of the climbing are well protected and it has an anchor- so I'd call it a sport route. Two stars out of five.
content.location:
On the southwest face of Cyclops Rock about 40' right of the start for

The Official Route of the 1984 Olympics

. The climb is easily identified as starting out of a recessed area of rock that overhangs slightly.

climbs.name: Goldilocks
climbs.fa: unknown

content.description: Some runout 5.8 face moves halfway up lead to a crux exit move in a bulging corner.
content.location: Near the right end of the southwest face, where the height of the rock has dropped considerably.

climbs.name: Fractured Fissure
climbs.fa: John Long, Brian Pohorff, October 1971, FFA: (TR) John Long, 1981, FL: Todd Gordon & Don Reid, May 1998

content.description: Steep double crack system with juggy finish.
content.protection: Standard rack, 2 bolts with long chains are available to rap off or take the easy walk off.
content.location: Northwest face The start is at the top of a gully,  one gully over from The Eye. Anchors provide a quick exit for The Eye as well.

climbs.name: Foul Fowl
climbs.fa: Woody Stark, Bill Briggs and Pat Wiedman, 1966

content.description:
Just left of Carolyn's Rump is a groove with vertical solution pockets leading up to a big nest next to a rap station on a slung horn.

Stem and pinch your way up this thing and try to console or shame yourself with the guidebook 5.6 rating as you sketch like mad on weird holds and sloping stances.
content.location: Just left of the distinctive chimney of Carolyn's Rump on the north face of the Cyclops.

climbs.name: The Eye
climbs.fa: Dick Webster and Harold Webster, 1957

content.description:
A great beginner route with excellent exposure. Rated 5.1 in Vogel's guidebook, this route in my opinion warrants a slightly stiffer rating. Begin in alcove up low-angle crack. Continue onto steep face with great holds to the top. Gear belay.

Also makes for a nice free solo at the end of the day.

Descent: walk east down the backside and back around (north) to your pack.

climbs.name: Dino Damage
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel, Sarah Vogel & Todd Gordon, 1993

content.description: Start off the large ledge and climb a bolted face with horizontals, being careful of loose flakes up higher.
content.location:
To the right of Leaders Fright and to the left of

The Official Route of the 1984 Olympics

.

Either approach via an easy 5th class slot to climbers left leading to a large ledge and the base of the climb or do the start of 1984 Olympics eventually moving back left.

climbs.name: Circe Direct
climbs.fa: unknown

content.description: This is the direct start to Circe. Instead of starting on The Eye, begin on the 5.8 offwidth directly below Circe. This avoids the unappealing start to Circe and makes it into a nice climb. It was climbed by Mike Duncan and me on 28 March 2001, but we doubt that was a first ascent even though it's not listed in the guidebooks.
content.protection: Standard Rack, maybe a large piece for the start

climbs.name: Circe
climbs.fa: Dick Webster and Harold Webster, 1967

content.description: From a short distance up The Eye, traverse right onto the exposed arête.  Exciting moves take you up the arête.  Thin protection.

climbs.name: Carolyn's Rump
climbs.fa: John Wolfe, Carolyn Gilliland, and Ed Zombro, 1967

content.description: An easy chimney becomes steep and shallow for its crux exit sequence.  The scramble down is a bit tricky - the easiest way is to climb up to the top of the rock and then go down the back side.  This climb is in the shade most of the time.
content.location: North end of the northeast face.

climbs.name: Business Trip
climbs.fa: Manfred Buchroilhuer, January 1990

content.description: Begins in a chimney.  At the top of this, make a right turn up some slabs to an easy crack pulling through a "roof".
content.protection: Very little gear.  Maybe towards the bottom entering the chimney and at the very top.  If you choose to rope up, bring LONG slings due to the sharp turn you take on the route past the chimney.
content.location:
Just a little to the left of Thin Red Line.

To get down, continue up and over the top and descend the back side as for The Eye.

climbs.name: Aye, Aye
climbs.fa: Todd & Donette Swain 01-2008

content.description:
Directly across from Masochism on the Potato Head are two parallel right slanting cracks. These cracks are on the lower north face of the Cyclops.

Climb the right hand (toward HVCG) crack.

climbs.name: Are We Ourselves
climbs.fa: Dave Evans 1984

content.description: This route ascends the southwest face of Cyclops. It starts from the left of the formation and works up and to the right, finally exiting about midway along the top of the formation. It can be started in numerous ways: begin with the bolt on "The Official Route"..., and it will be 10B; go directly for the left facing flake, and it will be much easier; start to the right and up the ledge system, minimal difficulty. Overcome the flake, work right then up. You'll find two anchors here. Go up the plates and through the notch. I've given more of a description than I usually do because this is an excellent route for a novice and for someone doing first leads around seven or eight.
